text: Construction, development and operation activities are subject to oversight by the provincial government and strict compliance procedures.

Industry is expected to operate in compliance with all conditions and requirements identified by the provincial government. These conditions and requirements are set out in the environmental assessment certificate or individual permit.

Compliance and enforcement actions vary, and often depend on the severity of the situation requiring attention or correction. When non-compliances are identified the goal is always the same: to bring the company back into compliance.

The list below includes compliance actions imposed to date by the BC Oil and Gas Commission and British Columbia’s Environmental Assessment Office. Some compliance actions of the BC Oil & Gas Commission are not included at this time, but will be added to the site soon. For a complete up-to-date list of BC Oil & Gas Commission compliance actions, please go to the [BC Oil and Gas Commission website](https://www.bcogc.ca/data-reports/compliance-enforcement/).
For a full list of all authorizations and their associated requirements, please visit the [Authorizations](/project/2/authorizations) page.

docs.description: Order issued relating to Condition 23 of Schedule B to EAC E14-03 requires that the Certificate Holder must, at least six months prior to carrying out activities that may affect tenured rights, notify all known tenure holders who hold tenures as of the date of the EAC.
docs.name: Section 34 Order - Traplines
docs.author: Environmental Assessment Office

docs.description: Order issued relating to Condition 17 of Schedule B to EAC E14-03 requires that the Certificate Holder must,prior to Construction, for any red and blue listed plants and ecological communities identified by the British Columbia Conservation Data Centre, conduct site habitat assessment surveys for all locations within the Certified Pipeline Corridor, and propose mitigation to address adverse effects to those plants and ecological communities. The survey results and mitigations are to be included in relevant permit applications.
docs.name: Section 34 Order - Endangered Plants and Ecosystems
docs.author: Environmental Assessment Office

docs.description: An inspection was completed as a result of a complaint received to the EAO on January 25, 2019.  The onsite component of this inspection focused on work within “Section 7” of the Project, southwest of Houston BC, including the Camp 9A location (also known as Multi Use Area 9A and 9B) located at UTM 9U 591502 6008707
